title: Intrapancreatic Accessory Spleen: A Diagnosis Not to Forget!
patient: A 69-year-old male patient without known pancreatic disease was referred for endoscopic ultrasound (EUS) examination for suspected choledocholithiasis. Endosonographically, a 5-mm hypoechoic lesion was observed in the pancreatic tail. It was a round-shaped, well-defined, homogeneous pancreatic mass with identical echogenicity to the spleen (Fig ). The remaining pancreas was unremarkable. After the administration of sonographic contrast (SonoVue®; Bracco, Milano, Italy), the lesion showed a uniform hyperenhancing appearance compared with the surrounding pancreas (Fig ). The lesion characterization was complemented by EUS-elastography, which displayed a homogeneous, green elastographic pattern (Fig ). These features together were highly suggestive of a benign pancreatic solid lesion such as an IPAS or a benign neuroendocrine tumor (NET). Interposition of the splenic artery between the probe and the lesion precluded EUS-guided fine-needle aspiration (FNA). Therefore, a definite pathological diagnosis was not possible to achieve, and the patient was scheduled for a second EUS within 6 months to re-evaluate the pancreatic lesion.
